title: How to save my DVD collection so I can view or stream them on my TV without using the disc or the DVD player - Quora

response.answer_text: You’ll have to ‘rip’ them, with any DVD ripper software.Ripping them, basically means bypassing copyright protection, and copying the content to a harddrive.The content will be very big in size, like usually between 2 to 6GB for a movie. After ripping, you can convert the content, using free programs like Handbrake, or some other DVD programs. Most free DVD encoding programs, either have excellent video encoding, or excellent audio encoding. But some paid versions have both of them. The best video codec to this date, is h.265.A 2 hour full size movie can easily fit in a 400MB file; and it’s preferred for 4k content (or content above 1080p). That’s about 10x smaller than MPeG 2. The second best video codec, is h.264. I personally use this one, because it’s more common. A 2 hour video can easily fit in 600–800MB filesize, which is still a substantial compression vs the MPeG 2 compression used on traditional DVDs. The best audio codec is Opus. From lossless (1000+kbits) audio, it can create near CD quality at 48kbits, or even 24kbits sounds pretty good! This format is preferred, however it’s not always compatible with a lot of media players out there.The second best is OGG. The same audio can be compressed in 80kbits, and still sound very good! Compare that to MP3, which needs at least 128kbits, but preferably 160kbits to sound good! After you’ve ripped and converted all formats, you can put them on a harddrive or SSD (a 128GB drive can easily host over 150 full size movies)

“How can I save my DVD collection so I can view or stream them on my TV without using the disc or the DVD player?” Typically people will use their computer and special software to rip their physical media collection and then store the data either on a portable harddrive that they connect directly to a compatible TV OR they use a streaming device that can access the ripped content stored on their computer by using an app like Plex.

response.answer_text: It can be done …obviously as Netflix does it, but is not as good an idea as for CDs. The file size is 5gigabytes or 40 gigabytes for Blu-ray . Which really eats into hard disc space.We tend to only watch a dvd a few times , so is it worth the bother.?The studios organised anti piracy options into their discs ,so software to rip them is less available.

I use MakeMKV to rip DVDs and Blu-ray Discs: turn them into MKV files that I can watch on some devices. I then use Handbrake to turn those MKV files into iTunes compatible mp4s or m4vs. I THEN drag them into the TV app … and watch them on the Apple TV that’s connected to my telly …
